author: @mr.nonederful3314
text: As a potential alternative for those having issues with the ico you could try the this (I have no idea if this will create problems down the road, I'm only as far as you). I wasn't able to get the 'iconbitmap' to work on Win 10 Py 3.6 and I also wanted the ico in a subdirectory. This worked for me.  I added title and icon to 'app' at the end of the code:  app = YourAppName() app.title("This is my app title") app.geometry("600x480") # this will prob get addressed in upcoming vid. img = tk.PhotoImage(file='C:/Users/YourDir/ProjectDir/Src/Imgs/favicon.gif') # '.ico', '.png' and '.gif' all worked for me on Windowz.  app.iconphoto(True, img) app.mainloop()

author: @forresterickson6225
text: I have been working with other tutorials too including one with Text window.  I have tried to add a Text window to this example but found the constant END was not defined and the window did not open. I traced it down to a difference in the import. Using "from tkinter import *"  the constant was defined (it was 'end') but using the method of this tutorial, "import tkinter as tk" the constant END was not defined.    I defined it to clear the error when I try to use it but the window never opens in the example so I think either I have to rewrite to use the import * method or I need to understand how to over come the import as tk difference.  Any suggestions out there?

author: @garryhurst9337
text: For those of you who may be trying to follow on other operating systems,  to make this work cross platform add "from sys import platform", then add:  if platform == "darwin":      icon = "clienticon.icns" elif platform == "win32":       icon = "clienticon.ico"  then change tk.Tk.iconbitmap(self, default="clienticon.ico") to read: tk.Tk.iconbitmap(self, icon)  Note:  tk.Tk.iconbitmap(self, default="clienticon.ico") will throw an error on OS X  Thank you sentdex for these really really great tutorials, and thank you so much for explaining things and adding the "why?" to the explanation!

author: @mieszkometody
text: after some fight with icon I put in the class inherit from tk.Tk :  if os.name == "nt":  # windows     self.iconbitmap("icon_name.ico")  else:  # linux. Dont know about mac     icon = PhotoImage(file='myicon.gif')      self.tk.call('wm', 'iconphoto', self._w, icon)  in emergency you can use black and white .xmb file: self.iconbitmap("@icon_name.xbm")  source: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11176638/python-setting-application-icon?noredirect=1&lq=1

author: @olivercopleston
text: If you're running the program as root, try: root.iconbitmap("favicon.ico")  That got it working for me.

author: @Jigatree
text: To get this bitmap method to work on linux I needed .mbc files which looked nasty and B+W. After some searching I got this to work for gifs.  icon = tk.PhotoImage(file='Icon.gif') self.tk.call('wm', 'iconphoto', self._w, icon)

author: @wouterdroog4210
text: First of I want to thank Harrison for putting this material on-line for us to learn!  For me changing the icon didn't work until I assigned the default parameter without specifying the word default. As long as I put in default it will go to the default icon no matter what I assign to default. So, the code that worked for me is: tk.Tk.iconbitmap(self, "icon.ico")
